awd_titl_txt: Personalizing Mathematics to Maximize Relevance and Skill for Tomorrow's STEM Workforce
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM) by developing and testing an intervention system to engage students in meaningful STEM problem posing and solving and by providing an on-line tool to assist teachers in guiding the process.

This is a collaborative project involving three different institutions to use personalization strategies to strengthen students' algebraic interest and skills in STEM pathways. The project will build an environment to support algebra students' learning key content in the context of their STEM career interests by posing and solving story problems. The problems posed are based on algebra content, related to STEM career paths, and embedded in a technological interface. The innovation, of using personalized problem-posing tasks to entice students to recognize, formulate, and solve problems, framed by how mathematics is used in STEM careers, is a compelling strategy to engage students and promote STEM learning.  

The project will examine an instructional intervention for high school algebra that connects course content to the STEM careers to increase students' interest in those fields. In addition, within the career pathways construct, the study will investigate the effect of personalized problem posing as well as problem solving on students' algebra skill development. Specifically, the project will examine how different scaffolding approaches to STEM career problem-posing (e.g., expert video vs. examples) affect the problems posed by students and the interest and knowledge that they gain. The findings of the study have the potential will build evidence for both personalization and student generation of problem-solving tasks on improving student learning in algebra and interest in STEM fields. The study seeks to confirm a taxonomy of three features necessary for successful personalized learning: content should be personalized so that it aligns to student interests, problems must be sufficiently granular to more precisely align to student interests, and students must perceive ownership in the process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we (1) reviewed the literature about personalized learning to discover examples and theory that informed our design for personalized math learning, (2) interviewed STEM career practitioners to learn about math in their work, (3) surveyed students to analyze their career and math interests and guide our career-personalized designs, then (4) tested how personalizing problem-posing and -solving activities with career-focused content could affect career interests and math interest and learning. Then we (5) organized the products we developed for teachers and learners to use.

1. We conducted a systematic literature review examining 376 studies of personalized learning (PL) and found that PL designs target a wide variety of learner characteristics and outcomes, often simultaneously. Most researchers developed PL materials without aligning design choices to theories or research on learning and development. We proposed that a theoretically guided approach provides a “theory of change” that explains why PL designs should deliver targeted outcomes for learners, and why they should succeed. We recommended researchers design in ways that can explain how each of their PL components contribute to learner outcomes.

2. We surveyed and interviewed 104 STEM career practitioners from fields ranging from engineering to healthcare to finance. We found that linear algebraic relationships are common in their workplaces, but non-linear functions are rarely used. STEM practitioners often use algebra concepts as calculations or formulas rather than symbolic equations, and many justify the importance of algebra in its relation to statistics and data analysis. STEM practitioners described the purpose of learning algebra as related to problem solving, logic, and patterns, and highlight that algebraic functions can have limited utility in the real world given the messiness of phenomena and the diverse ways in which things are represented and modelled. This research has important implications for future math learning standards.

3. We also surveyed 770 middle school, high school, and community college students about their interest in STEM careers and in mathematics, and how they thought mathematics was related to STEM careers. We found that interest in mathematics predicted interest in many, but not all, STEM career categories. Students’ perceptions of how math is used in their chosen career area predicted their interest in math, and their interest in some STEM career areas. We also used these lengthy surveys to examine how learners valuing, enjoyment, and knowledge of math contributed to their interest. We designed a new, briefer scale to reflect these components so researchers and educators could quickly assess future students’ interests. We found this shorter 8-item scale and to be just as successful at predicting STEM career interests as the 22-item survey.

4. In our pilot study, we asked 39 community college students to pose algebra problems based on their STEM career interests. We found that problem-posing led to a significant increase in mathematics interest. We did not find that the scaffolds students used during problem-posing (video, templates, vignettes and example problems) influenced their interest, though some evidence indicated that watching videos that demonstrated algebra in the STEM workplace increased students’ general math interest and working with templates increased students’ interest in the assignment. We next conducted a randomized control trial where students in middle school (n=135) high school (n=82), and college (n=255) were randomly assigned to four conditions and spent 3-4 units using the ASSISTments math learning platform to: (1) solve general interest story problems, (2) solve story problems personalized to their career interests, (3) pose their own story problems personalized to their career interests, and (4) pose their own story problems personalized to their popular culture interests. Students assigned to personalized problem-posing activities learned more algebra compared to general interest problem solvers, our “business as usual” (BAU) condition. The career-solving condition did not differ significantly from BAU. While learning effects were promising, problem-posing activities decreased students’ STEM career interest, compared to solving career or general interest problems. For middle and high school students, posing problems about out-of-school interests related to popular culture areas negatively affected the enjoyment they reported for math. This study advances research and theories of personalized learning and also guides the practical implementation of future career personalized interventions.

5. We developed ASSISTments assignments that personalize algebra instruction to 8 career and 4 popular culture interest areas. A YouTube channel hosts 386 videos of STEM practitioners or popular culture interest enthusiasts telling stories of algebra in daily life and 12 more videos of students and teachers working with our materials in classrooms. These videos are organized by math and interest topics on our Stories of Algebra website (https://sites.google.com/view/stories-of-algebra), which also contains 225 templates students can use to consider interest areas and algebraic equations while building math problems. The papers and presentations that document our work appear on the website, and an award-winning video about the project appears in the STEM For All Video Showcase (https://stemforall2021.videohall.com/presentations/1917?display_media=video).
